home_top: Placy's map shows places, based on your music preferences. Reviews and rankings are sometimes helpful, but honestly, music taste tells a lot about you.
home_microsoft: As a map app app provider, Placy, was chosen for Microsoft's Startups Program.
home_wired: Placy is creating a common language of emotion and logic, to find places and resist the homogenisation of the city.
home_urban_rhythm:
In Tokyo, most of the people chose major stations such as Shibuya or Shinjuku for going out, thus minor but local stations seem to be forgotten.

In this collaborative project with JR-EAST, We re-represented the cultural value of each 30 station in Yamanote-Line through the lens of music.

We Provided three things; web app where people can find stations based on music, pamphlet for each stations that depict surrounding music characteristics, and playlist for each station.
about_mission:
We sometimes feel vaguely that our city is boring.

The scenery has become homogenised everywhere you go.

At the risk of sounding pretentious, we see the cause as being that the space and meaning layers are disconnected.

No matter how appealing the space, if it is disconnected from its meaning in its virtual presence, people will judge it by oversimplified list-based perspectives such as reviews and rankings.

With that in mind, we are developing a map to help you find places based on music.

We provide users the experience of finding places based on their instinct, not on faked or homogenised metrics.

In the near future, we will add movies books and other mediums. So you enter your preferences and we translate that accross to places that you may like.

Our mission is to connect space to its meaning.
about_explanation:
Every city has its "rhythm" Rich culture and millions of stories over the ages have become ingrained in the fabric of the city, echoing out its “rhythm”.

It is what makes the city beautiful and lovable. Sometimes, when you exploring a city, you are drawn to a place, as magnets are drawn to each other; proof that your inner “rhythm” resonates with the city's rhythm.

Whether it be a shiny and extravagant part of town, or a the gloomy yet human neighborhood, there is a place that matches your rhythm, out there waiting for you to find.

Forget the reviews. Follow your rhythm.
career_top: Placy's competencies are in urban modeling, spatial data analysis and computer science, with our members having backgrounds in each. We are currently looking for new members to work with us. We look forward to hearing from you!

positions.title: Software Engineer (CTO candidates)
positions.description: Mobile apps (IOS & Android) and the development of contract projects

jobDescription.text1: Refactoring the front-end, back-end, and adding infrastructure to existing projects
jobDescription.text2: Design and database organization for future app and company purposes
jobDescription.text3: Recruitment and management of a small team of engineers to achieve the above goals

skills.text1: Experience using cloud infrastructure such as Azure, AWS, GCP
skills.text2: Development experience using Swift, Flutter, Python, PostgreSQL

otherSkills.text2: Knowledge of machine learning about music and recommendations
otherSkills.text3: Experience in spatial data analysis (OSM and QGIS)

soma.name: Soma Suzuki
soma.text: After completing an undergraduate degree at Kyoto University in physics, he received a Master's degree in city spatial analysis from UCL Bartlett School in London.

kazu.name: Morishita Kazuyuki
kazu.text: Graduated form University of Melbourne's department of Mathematics. Works as an actuary in a financial institution. In Placy he is responsible for the construction and analysis of the spacial database.

hideo.name: Hideo Daikoku
hideo.text: Born and raised in New Delhi, India. Hideo is currently a 4th year student at Keio University's Faculty of Environment. He is in charge of software development and design at Placy.

marina.name: marina
marina.text: Currently studying communication engineering at Tokyo Denki University's Faculty of Engineering. In Placy, she is in charge of the iOS app development.

miki.name: Miki
miki.text: Currently studying at Meiji University's Faculty of Interdisciplinary Mathematical Science. Responsible for mobile app development in Placy. He likes coffee and working as a barista.

stephen.name: Stephen Law
stephen.text: Research Fellow at the Alan Turing National Institute of Data Science. Responsible for the establishment of the London branch and urban modeling.

todd.name: Todd Perry
todd.text: Has worked as a data analysis engineer in London at Huq Industries. He is responsible for software development and infrastructure in Placy.

sp4ghet.name: sp4ghet
sp4ghet.text: Undergraduate at UCL, studying Theoretical Physics. Prior to uni, he developed and researched software for plant factories. Hobbies include creative coding and VJ-ing.

mirei.name: Mirei Takada
mirei.text: A student majoring in Business and Economics at Sophia University. In charge of Marketing/PR at Placy. As I was born in 2000, and I like artists my age like Mega Shinnosuke.

eisuke.name: Mizuguchi Eisuke
eisuke.text: Representative at "Law and Theory", a collective of music lawyers which provides free legal consultation services to musicians. He has worked on many projects with clients such as artists, music labels, and music-related companies.

jono.name: Jono Hibiki
jono.text: Worked at "Unit", an electronic music club at the heart of the urban music scene, after graduating Kyoto University. He is currently a graduate student at the The Kyoto College of Graduate Studies for Informatics. Mobile developer at Placy.

moriya.name: Naoki Moriya
moriya.text: In October 2017, a month after retiring from his previous job, Moriya opened Omoteochō Nichōme's very own Gyōza No Sekai. In March 2019, he opened a second store: the Asian Civic Center in Omotechō's Sanchōme. In November of the same year he started a Design Neon production business.

projects_urban:
In Tokyo, most of the people chose major stations such as Shibuya or Shinjuku for going out, thus minor but local stations seem to be forgotten.

In this collaborative project with JR-EAST, We re-represented the cultural value of each 30 station in Yamanote-Line through the lens of music.

We Provided three things; web app where people can find stations based on music, pamphlet for each stations that depict surrounding music characteristics, and playlist for each station.
projects_shibuya_cast: In the vicinity of Tokyu's Shibuya Cast building, we performed an analysis based on Placy's app data. We compared the characteristics of the music users listen to, between vititors to the area of Shibuya Cast, with the rest of Shibuya.
projects_shibuya_sound: Shibuya is changing rapidly from month to month. This project is archiving Shibuya from the perspective of "sound". It will generate a "Sound of Shibuya" based on Placy's user data and create a vinyl record postacrd; which you can actually play on your record player. (It is currently in production, but won't be long!)
projects_post_quarantine:
Cities are the central nodes of our modern economy; hubs of creativity and innovation. Our globalised system relies on us living collectively, but pandemics are inherently anti-city, as they could force the breakdown of collective cooperation. How will our cities evolve, to adapt to this new reality?

Cities across the world are establishing unique initiatives and projects to combat the effects of this situation; and by exploring each city's approach, perhaps we can gain a glimpse of our post quarantine world.
projects_placelist:
Welcome to the Placy Place List.
On this page, you can create a playlist for your favorite places and share it with everyone.
While the self isolation request continues, many shops and restaurants are
taking initiative, for example, by selling advance tickets and making calls for donations.
We believe that by sharing places with others through the lens of music, more people will care and support that place.
Let's make it happen!
